explanations: The French "de meilleur pour nous" (best for us / more favorable for us) suggests a belief adopted for psychological comfort or as a more charitable view from a human perspective. The translation "for our advantage" subtly shifts this to a more utilitarian or self-serving motivation, implying the belief is held because it offers a tangible benefit or gain, thus altering the perceived reason behind the belief.

This translation introduces two subtle manipulations. "Les Sçavans" (scholars, learned men) is rendered as "the Virtuoso's." In the 17th-century English context, "virtuoso" referred to individuals interested in arts and sciences, including Royal Society members, but could also carry connotations of a gentleman amateur or collector, subtly altering the image from the more formally academic French "Sçavans" and domesticating it for an English audience. Concurrently, "toutes les peines que se donnent" (all the efforts/pains they take) is translated and expanded to "the pains and studies"; the addition of "and studies" specifies intellectual labor, whereas "peines" is broader, thus subtly shifting the emphasis of the scientific endeavor.

The French "Les Curieux vont la voir" (The curious go to see it) is translated with heightened intensity as "the curious run to gaze on it." The addition of "run" implies an urgency and eagerness not present in "vont" (go), and "gaze" suggests a more intense, perhaps prolonged, act of looking than the general "voir" (see). This subtly changes the tone, portraying the Jovian curious with a greater degree of excitement or fervor than the more neutral description in the original.

chunks.sourceHtml: P074: Si ce n'estoit, dit la Marquise, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?
chunks.manualHtml: P068: If it were not, said the Marchioness, that it is not very satisfactory to know that from Iupiter they cannot discover us without a Telescope. I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?
chunks.aiHtml: P068: If it were not, said the Marchioness, that it is not very satisfactory to know that from Iupiter they cannot discover us without a Telescope. I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?
explanations: The original French 'agreable' (pleasant, agreeable) expresses a direct, personal feeling of (un)pleasantness regarding a piece of knowledge. The translation 'satisfactory' shifts this to a more detached, cognitive judgment of adequacy. This changes the tone of the Marquise's remark, making her sound less spontaneously emotive and more formally evaluative, subtly altering the reader's perception of her character's expression and the immediacy of her feelings.

The French 'dressées vers nous' (aimed, directed, or set up towards us) is a relatively neutral term for the positioning of telescopes. The English 'planted toward us', while it can mean positioned, often carries additional connotations of being fixed, firmly established, or even strategically placed (akin to planting artillery or a flag). This subtly alters the image of the telescopes, potentially making them seem more static, imposing, or deliberately set with a specific intent than the more general 'dressées' implies, thus shifting the reader's perception of the imagined scene.

The original French 'comme les nostres le sont vers luy' literally means 'as ours are [directed/aimed] towards him,' simply indicating the orientation or state of Earth's telescopes relative to Jupiter. The translation 'as ours are to behold him' adds an explicit statement of purpose ('to behold him') which is only implied in the original French. Furthermore, the choice of the verb 'behold' is more literary and carries a sense of formal observation, wonder, or awe, adding a connotative layer and a degree of elaboration not present in the straightforward French phrasing. This addition of explicit purpose and shift in lexical choice subtly alters the original's conciseness and tone.

chunks.sourceHtml: P075: Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y a fait le procés à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, qui est fort petit, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne avec les siennes. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.
chunks.manualHtml: P069: Hold, said I, that's not so soon done as you imagine: should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth, and know it, yet our Earth is not our selves; there would not be the least suspicion that 'tis inhabited: and should any one chance to entertain such a thought, God knows how the whole World of Iupiter would mock him. Nay possibly we have already been the cause of arraigning some of their Philosophers for holding that we have a Being in Nature. In the mean time I rather believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter have imployment enough in making discoveries in their own Planet, without ever dreaming of us; it is so big, that if they have the Art of Navigation, their Christopher Columba's have most certainly imployment enough. It must needs be that the people of that World do not know the hundredth part of it; whereas in Mercury, which is very little, they are all Neighbours, live very familiarly together, and count it but a Walk, to make a turn about their World. If they do not see us from Iupiter, you will easily judge that the people of that Planet do much less see Venus and Mercury, which are both lesser Worlds, and more distant from him. But to make amends, his inhabitants see Mars, and their own four Moons, and Saturn with his. These are Planets enough to perplex their Astronomers, and Nature has been so kind to conceal the rest of the Universe from them.

explanations: The original French suggests that the inhabitants of Jupiter ('les Peuples de ce Monde-là') might not know 'la centiéme partie des autres Peuples' (the hundredth part of the other Peoples) existing on their own vast planet. This points to a potential for complex social dynamics, such as fragmentation or lack of inter-societal awareness among different groups of Jovians. The English translation changes 'des autres Peuples' (of the other Peoples) to 'of it,' making the object of ignorance the planet Jupiter itself ('that World'). This alteration shifts the meaning from a lack of knowledge about *other societies* on Jupiter to a lack of *geographical knowledge* of their own planet. This subtly removes the social dimension of Fontenelle's speculation, focusing instead on the physical scale and explorability of the planet, thereby manipulating the reader's perception by downplaying potential social commentary for a more straightforward scientific observation.

The French original states that Jovian philosophers might have been prosecuted for wanting to 'soûtenir que nous estions' (maintain that we existed/were). This is a general existential claim. The English translation renders this as 'for holding that we have a Being in Nature.' The addition of 'in Nature' specifies and frames the controversial belief within the discourse of Natural Philosophy, a term and field of study highly prominent in England during the late 17th century. While 'arraigning' is a suitable translation for 'fait le procés à,' the qualification 'in Nature' subtly alters the original's broader, simpler statement about existence. It recasts the Jovian philosophers' 'heresy' into terms more familiar to contemporary English intellectual debates, potentially narrowing Fontenelle's original, more open-ended philosophical point and aligning it more closely with a specific scientific-philosophical framework then current in England, thereby manipulating the reader's understanding of the nature of the persecuted belief.

chunks.sourceHtml: P076: Quoy, dit la Marquise, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand Tourbillon seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.
chunks.manualHtml: P070: How, said the Marchioness, do you count that a kindness? Without doubt it is, said I, there are in all this great Vortex sixteen Planets. Nature, who would save us the trouble of studying all their motions, has let us see but seven of them, is not that a great kindness? But we, who know not how to value it, have taken a course to find out the other nine that were conceal'd, and are punish'd for our pains by the great labour that Astronomy at present requires.

explanations: The French "une grace" in this context suggests a significant favour, boon, or even a blessing, fitting the dialogue's elevated tone regarding Nature's actions. Translating it as "a kindness" makes the concept more general and less impactful. This subtly alters the tone and diminishes the perceived magnanimity or special quality of Nature's supposed act as initially questioned by the Marquise and posited by the philosopher.

The French verb "montre" (shows) casts Nature as an active agent in selectively presenting information. The translation "has let us see" shifts Nature to a more passive role, merely permitting humans to see rather than actively revealing. This alteration subtly changes the reader's understanding of Nature's agency and its relationship with human observers in the popularization of scientific ideas.

The French "une assez grande faveur" translates to "a rather/sufficiently great favour," implying a significant, measured gift, often from a superior entity like the personified Nature. The English "a great kindness" loses the nuance of "assez" (rather/sufficiently) and substitutes "faveur" (favour, a specific boon) with the more general and less formal "kindness." This subtly alters the tone, diminishing the original's emphasis on Nature bestowing a specific, considerable benefit and potentially downplaying the sense of a hierarchical relationship.

The French "nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons" (we do so well/are so clever that we catch/discover them) highlights human ingenuity and success, possibly with an ironic undertone characteristic of Fontenelle's popularizing style. The translation "have taken a course to find out" omits the emphatic "si bien" (so well/so cleverly). This omission neutralizes the original's characterization of human effort, downplaying the cleverness or remarkable nature of the discoveries and presenting them as a more mundane, procedural undertaking. This shifts the perception of human agency and achievement in the context of scientific advancement.

chunks.sourceHtml: P077: Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
chunks.manualHtml: P071: I find, says she, by that number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn ought to have five Moons. He has so, says I, and of those five, two are but lately discovered; but there is a thing yet much more remarkable, one of his years being thirty of ours, and by consequence there being Countreys in him, whose night is of fifteen years continuance, guess you what Nature has invented to inlighten such terrible nights. She was not satisfy'd with bestowing five Moons upon Saturn, but she has also inclos'd him with a great Circle or Ring, which is high enough raised to be out of the Shadow of the Body of that Planet, and continually reflects the Light of the Sun upon those places that do not see him.

explanations: The original French describes Nature's action as "mis autour de luy" (put around him) a ring, and then describes the ring as something "qui l'environne entierement" (which surrounds him entirely). These are neutral terms focusing on placement and the resulting spatial relationship. The translation consolidates this into the verb "inclos'd him with". While "inclose" (enclose) can mean "surround" or "encompass," it often carries stronger connotations of "shutting in," "confining," or "fencing off." This choice of verb subtly alters the connotation of Nature's action from one of simple provision and surrounding to one that could imply a more complete containment or the creation of a boundary, a nuance not explicitly present or emphasized in Fontenelle's more straightforward description. This may subtly shift the reader's perception of the ring's function or Saturn's status.

chunks.sourceHtml: P078: En verité, dit la Marquise, de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a point de Lune. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des Phosphores, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. Peut-estre Mars a-t-il de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des Phosphores naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?
chunks.manualHtml:
P072: Seriously and truly, says the Marchioness, with an Air of one astonish'd, all this is a work of great Order, it is very visible that Nature had in her eye the Necessities of every living Being, and that the Distribution of Moons was not a thing done at random. There's none share in it but the Planets farthest distant from the Sun, viz. the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for it was not worth the while to give them to Venus and Mercury, who receive but too much Light, whose Nights are short, and which they esteem a much greater benefit of Nature than their Days.

P073: But stay, says she, methinks Mars, who is father remov'd from the Sun than the Earth is, has no Moon. It cannot be deny'd, said I, he has none, and therefore he must have some other refuge in his nights than we know of. You have seen those Phosphores, of either dry or liquid matter, which receiving the Light of the Sun, imbibe it, and diffusing it in the dark, give a considerable light. Perhaps Mars has great Rocks high rais'd, which are natural Phosphores, and which in the day time make a provision of Light, which they disburse in the night. You cannot deny that it would be a delightful spectacle to see all those Rocks lighted at Sunset, and make magnificent Illuminations without any Art. You know likewise that there are in America certain Birds so luminous, that they give light enough to read by in the dark. How do we know but Mars has a great many of those Birds, which at nightfall disperse themselves every where, and create a new day?

explanations: The French describes the Marquise as "withdrawing into herself with astonishment," indicating an internal reflection accompanying her surprise. The translation simplifies this to merely "astonish'd," omitting the introspective element. This subtly alters her characterization, portraying her as less thoughtful and more purely reactive, which can shift the reader's perception of her intellectual engagement.

The French "quelques Estres vivans" (some living beings) is translated as "every living Being." This significantly broadens the scope of Nature's providence from specific instances to a universal scale. This shift implies a more perfect, all-encompassing, and perhaps divinely ordained natural order, potentially aligning with more traditional theological views and subtly altering Fontenelle's more nuanced and speculative approach to scientific popularization.

The French "apparemment" (apparently, seemingly), which modifies "comptent" (consider/esteem), is omitted in the translation of the phrase "comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits" (apparently consider it a greater benefit) as "esteem a much greater benefit". This omission changes the statement from a supposition by the philosopher to a more factual assertion about how inhabitants of Venus and Mercury view their nights. This removes speculative nuance characteristic of Fontenelle's style, presenting the idea with a greater degree of certainty.

The French "ressources" (resources, means) is a neutral term for how Martians might cope with moonless nights. The translation "refuge" (a place of shelter from danger or trouble) carries a connotation of peril or adversity. This subtly alters the tone, suggesting Martian nights are harsher or more dangerous than the original implies, shifting the reader's perception of conditions on Mars.

The French "s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent" describes two absorption processes: materials "soak up" light and "are permeated by it." The translation "imbibe it, and diffusing it" keeps the first idea but changes the second process of thorough absorption ("s'en penetrent") to an emission process ("diffusing it"). This alters the scientific description of phosphorescence, misrepresenting one part of the described phenomenon by replacing a detail about absorption with the subsequent act of emission.

The French "rêpandre un nouveau jour" (to spread a new day/light) is translated to "create a new day." The verb "create" is significantly stronger than "rêpandre" (to spread), implying a fundamental act of bringing daylight into existence rather than merely distributing light. This subtly exaggerates the capability of the hypothetical luminous birds, making the idea sound more miraculous or fantastical than the original's more grounded speculation.

The French "un Spectacle assez agreable" (a quite/rather pleasant spectacle) expresses a moderate level of appreciation. The translation "a delightful spectacle" uses a much stronger adjective, significantly intensifying the expressed emotion. This makes the philosopher's hypothetical scenario sound more wondrous or amazing than the more reserved original, subtly altering the tone of the speculation.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.

P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.
chunks.manualHtml: P074: I am not satisfy'd, says she, neither with your Rocks nor your Birds; not but that it may be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter, 'tis a sign there is occasion for them. I should have been glad that all the Worlds far distant from the Sun had them likewise, but Mars I find makes a disagreeable exception. Ah! says I, if you look'd more into Philosophy than you do, you would accustom your self to find exceptions in the best Systems. There is ever something that agrees very well, and something that we make agree as well as we can, or else we let it alone, if we despair of succeeding well in it. Let us deal so with Mars: since he doth not favour us, let us e'en say no more of him. We should be sufficiently astonished if we were in Saturn, to see over our heads in the night that great Ring, which moving in form of a Semicircle from one end of the Horizon to the other, reflects the Light of the Sun, and performs the office of a perpetual Moon. And, says the Marchioness, laughing, must we not likewise have Inhabitants in that great Ring? Truly said I, however I may be bold enough to plant them every where else, I must confess, I dare not place any there, that Ring seems a habitation too irregular. But as for the five little Moons, I think we cannot well dispense with peopling them; if in the mean time that Ring be, as some suspect, no more than a circle of Moons that follow one another very close with an equal motion, and that the five little Moons are such as have made their escape from the great Circle, what an infinity of Worlds shall we have in that Vortex of Saturn? however it be, the people of Saturn, with all the help of that Ring, are miserable enough. It gives them light, but what sort of a light at that distance from the Sun? the Sun it self is to them but a small Star, pale and wan, and has only a little glittering and a feeble heat. Were they brought into the coldest of our Countrys, as Groenland or Lapland, you would see them melt and expire with heat. You give me, says the Marchioness, an Idea of Saturn that freezes me, as just now you heated me in your discourse of Mercury. It must needs be, says I, that two Worlds that are in the extermities of this great Vortex, should be opposite in all things.

explanations: The French "convient le plus juste du monde" implies a perfect or exact fit. The translation "agrees very well" significantly lessens this degree of precision. This subtly diminishes the asserted strength or accuracy of the scientific "Sistêmes" (Systems) being discussed, potentially making them seem less rigorously defined or certain than Fontenelle suggested.

The French "bien étonnez" translates to "very astonished" or "greatly astonished." The English translation "sufficiently astonished" moderates the intensity of this emotion. This toning down subtly reduces the sense of awe and wonder that Fontenelle aims to evoke regarding the cosmos, making the described experience less impactful.

The original "feroit l'effet de" means "would have the effect of" or "would act as," describing an observed phenomenon. The translation "performs the office of" introduces a teleological nuance, implying a designated role or function. This phrasing could subtly shift the reader's perception towards a universe operating by appointed roles rather than purely naturalistic effects, a nuance potentially aligning with contemporary English theological leanings which emphasized order and design.

The French uses the impersonal pronoun "on" ("one cannot dispense with..."), presenting the idea of populating moons as a general, logical consideration. The translation "I think we cannot..." personalizes this, attributing it directly to the philosopher's opinion. This shift subtly changes the nature of the assertion from a general speculative necessity to a personal conjecture, potentially altering the perceived objectivity of the argument.

The French "Que de Mondes!" is an exclamation meaning "So many worlds!" or "What a lot of worlds!", expressing a large but indefinite quantity. The translation "what an infinity of Worlds" introduces the specific and philosophically potent concept of "infinity." This significantly amplifies the claim, making Fontenelle's speculation seem more radical or definitive on this point than the original's more general exclamation, aligning it more forcefully with the controversial Enlightenment idea of an infinite universe.

In the French, "bien foible" (very weak) modifies both "éclat" (gleam/brightness) and "chaleur" (heat), meaning "only a very weak gleam and a very weak heat." The translation offers "a little glittering and a feeble heat." While "feeble" captures "foible" for heat, "a little glittering" for the light does not fully convey the intensity of "bien foible" (very weak) for "éclat." This subtly alters the description, making Saturn's sun seem to provide light that is comparatively less weak than its heat, shifting the balance of privation described by Fontenelle.

The French "suër à grosses gouttes" means "to sweat profusely" or "to sweat in big drops," a strong but physiologically recognizable human-like reaction. The translation "melt" substitutes this with a far more extreme, fantastical, and less biologically plausible image. This sensationalizes the description, potentially making the imagined inhabitants of Saturn seem less like varied forms of life and more like purely imaginary beings, which could alter the reader's engagement with Fontenelle's popularization of extraterrestrial life.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P081: Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..

P082: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.
chunks.manualHtml: P075: So then, says she, they must be wise in Saturn; for you told me, they are all fools in Mercury. If they are not wise in Saturn, said I, they are, at least in all appearance `very flegmatick: they are people that know not what it is to laugh, that require a whole day to answer to the least Question, and would look upon Cato of Vitica as a Buffoon or a Jack-pudding. I have a thought in my head, says she; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are lively, and all those of Saturn are dull; among us some are lively and some are dull, doth not this proceed from hence, that we being just in the middle between those other Worlds, participate of the extremities? There is no fixed and determinate Character for Man, some are fram'd like the Inhabitants of Mercury, others like those of Saturn, and we are a mixture of all species that are in the other Planets. I like that idea, said I, well enough, we make up so odd a kind of likeness, that it may be thought we are a Collection out of several different Worlds; and therefore 'tis convenient enough to be here, where we see all the other Worlds in compendium.

explanations: The original French 'trop badin & trop folâtre' describes Cato as 'too playful and too frolicsome,' indicating that the extremely serious Saturnians would perceive him as having an excess of lightheartedness. The translation changes this to 'as a Buffoon or a Jack-pudding.' These terms are significantly stronger and more pejorative. 'Buffoon' implies ridicule, and 'Jack-pudding' introduces a specific, culturally-bound English archetype of a low-comedy stage clown, which has no direct equivalent in the original's more general description. This shift intensifies the Saturnians' perceived judgment of Cato, altering it from an observation about behavior (excessive playfulness) to a contemptuous categorization of his person as a professional fool. This change manipulates the reader's understanding by altering the tone of the philosopher's remark, making the Saturnians seem more harshly judgmental and introducing a culturally specific, less refined comedic element than in Fontenelle's original, more subtly witty French.

chunks.sourceHtml: P083: Du moins, reprit la Marquise, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.
chunks.manualHtml: P076: At least, said the Marchioness, our World has one real convenience by the Scituation, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter or Saturn; and moreover we are seated just in a part of the Earth where we find excess neither of Heat nor Cold. Seriously, if a certain Philosopher gave thanks to Nature for making him a Man and not a Beast, a Greek and not a Barbarian, I for my share give her thanks for placing me in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in the most temperate place of that Planet. Believe me, Madam, said I, you may give her thanks that you are young and not old, young and fair, and not young and ugly; a young and fair French-woman, and not a young and fair Italian: these are things to be acknowledg'd as advantages as well as those you receive by the Scituation of your Vortex and the Temperature of your Countrey.

Seriously, if a certain Philosopher gave thanks to Nature for making him a Man and not a Beast, a Greek and not a Barbarian, I for my share give her thanks for placing me in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in the most temperate place of that Planet. Believe me, Madam, said I, you may give her thanks that you are young and not old, young and fair, and not young and ugly; a young and fair French-woman, and not a young and fair Italian: these are things to be acknowledg'd as advantages as well as those you receive by the Scituation of your Vortex and the Temperature of your Countrey.
explanations: The French "moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete" expresses the Marquise's *intention* or *desire* ("I want to give thanks") for her *state of being* ("for being on"). The translation changes this in two ways: 1. It omits "veux" (want to), altering her statement from an expression of intent ("I want to give thanks") to a direct declaration of action ("I give thanks"), making her tone more assertive and immediate than in the original. 2. It changes "d'estre sur" (for being on) to "for placing me in." This attributes a more active, deliberate role to "Nature" in her specific location. This subtly shifts the focus from gratitude for a circumstance to gratitude for an act of placement, potentially reinforcing a more providential worldview for the English reader. This is significant as Fontenelle's work was moving towards a view of the universe less dependent on continuous divine intervention.

The French "vous luy rendrez grace" (you will/would give her thanks), spoken by the philosopher, functions as a strong suggestion or a polite imperative regarding what the Marquise should be thankful for. The translation "you may give her thanks" replaces this with a modal of permission or possibility. This significantly softens the philosopher's assertion, changing his tone from confidently directive to merely suggestive. This alteration lessens the force of his argument about the value of personal attributes (youth, beauty, nationality) as sources of gratitude and subtly reframes his intellectual posture relative to the Marquise, potentially to make his (French) character seem less authoritative to an English audience or to conform to different stylistic norms.

The original French "Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de..." means "Here are indeed other subjects of gratitude/thankfulness than those that you draw from...". The translation "these are things to be acknowledg'd as advantages as well as those you receive by..." introduces two key manipulations: 1. "Sujets de reconnoissance" (subjects of gratitude/thankfulness) is rendered as "things to be acknowledg'd as advantages." This shifts the connotation from an emotional or moral appreciation inherent in "reconnoissance" towards a more pragmatic, utilitarian recognition of "advantages," subtly altering the philosophical and sentimental tone of the philosopher's remark. 2. The French comparative structure using "que" (than) suggests a contrast, implying these personal attributes are different, perhaps more significant, reasons for gratitude. The English "as well as" changes this to an additive structure, presenting the philosopher's points merely as additional items to the Marquise's list, rather than contrasting or re-prioritizing them. This weakens the gentle corrective nuance in his statement, making him sound like he is simply adding to her list rather than offering more compelling alternatives.

chunks.sourceHtml: P084: Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.
chunks.manualHtml: P077: Good God! said the Marchioness, let me acknowledge all, even to the Vortex where I am plac'd, the proportion of Happiness that has been measur'd out to us is very small, and we ought to be chary of it and lose none, and it is good to entertain such a relish and sense of even the most common and inconsiderable things, as may render them useful to us. If we desire only lively pleasures, we shall have few, stay long and pay dear for them. You will promise me then, said I, if I propose lively pleasures to you, you will remember me and my Vortices, and will be of our side. I will, said she, but you must provide that Philosophy still supply me with new pleasures. At least, said I, to morrow, I hope, you shall not fail of them. I have fixed Stars that will go beyond all that you have seen yet.

explanations: The original French 'laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout' expresses a desire to feel and show gratitude. The translation 'let me acknowledge all' shifts the meaning from an emotional expression of thankfulness to a more neutral, cognitive act of admission, thereby altering the Marquise's tone to be less warm and appreciative.

The French 'si on vous proposoit' uses the impersonal pronoun 'on' (one/they), referring to a general hypothetical offer of 'lively pleasures'. The translation 'if I propose' changes this to a specific, personal action by the philosopher ('I'). This alteration subtly makes the philosopher the potential source of these pleasures, changing the dynamic of the conversation and potentially his perceived role.

The French 'que vous vous borneriez à nous?' asks if the Marquise would 'limit herself to' or 'be content with' the philosopher and his intellectual offerings, implying a choice of personal satisfaction. The translation 'and will be of our side.' fundamentally changes this meaning to a question of allegiance or taking a partisan stance. This introduces a confrontational or factional connotation not present in the original, manipulating the reader's understanding of the Marquise's commitment.

chunks.sourceHtml: P085: CINQUIEME SOIR.
chunks.manualHtml: P078: THE Fifth Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P078: THE Fifth Evening.

chunks.sourceHtml: P086:. La Marquise sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de cinquante millions de lieuës; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuës, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.
chunks.manualHtml: P079: THe Marchioness was sensibly impatient to know what would become of the fixed Stars. Shall they be inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or shall they not? or what shall we do with them? Perhaps, said I, you might guess, if you would; the fixed Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than some fifty millions of Leagues, and if you vex an Astronomer, he'l put them a great way further. The distance of the Sun from the most distant Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance of the Sun or of the Earth from the fixed Stars, men do not take the pains to compute it. Their Light, as you see, is bright and lively enough. If they receive it from the Sun, they must needs receive it in a weak condition after a passage of fifty millions of Leagues, and they must return it to us through the same distance by a Reflection, that must yet much more impair the strength of it. It may seem impossible that a Light that is made by Reflection, and has travail'd twice fifty millions of Leagues, should retain that force and vivacity which we find in the fixed Stars. You see then they are all luminous in themselves, and in a word, are so many Suns.

explanations: The French impersonal pronoun "on" (meaning "one," "people," or "they") in the phrase "on ne prend pas la peine de la compter" (one/people do not take the pains to compute it) is translated as "men" in the corresponding English phrase "men do not take the pains to compute it." While "men" could be used generically for "people" in 17th-century English, Fontenelle's work was pioneering in its effort to make science accessible, particularly to women. This translation choice, by specifying "men," subtly narrows the general and inclusive scope of Fontenelle's "on." This results in altering the perception of who is engaging (or not engaging) in such scientific considerations, potentially undermining the original's inclusive tone which was a key feature of Fontenelle's popularization of science.

The original French "Il seroit impossible" (It would be impossible) presents a strong, near-certain logical deduction as part of the philosopher's argument about why fixed stars must be self-luminous. The translation "It may seem impossible" significantly weakens this assertion. The introduction of "may seem" shifts the statement from a confident conclusion (based on the preceding reasoning) to one about mere appearance or possibility. This alters the rhetorical force and the perceived certainty of the scientific argument being presented to the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P087: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé..
chunks.manualHtml: P080: I am not out of the way, cry'd the Marchioness, whether I go, or whether you lead me, you are going to tell me, That the fixed Stars are so many Suns, our Sun is the Center of a Vortex that turns about him, why should not every fixed Star be the Center of a Vortex that has likewise a motion about it? Our Sun has Planets which it inlightens, why should not every fixed Star have the like? I have no Answer, said I, but that of Phedra to Enone, 'Tis you have said it.
chunks.aiHtml: P080: I am not out of the way, cry'd the Marchioness, whether I go, or whether you lead me, you are going to tell me, That the fixed Stars are so many Suns, our Sun is the Center of a Vortex that turns about him, why should not every fixed Star be the Center of a Vortex that has likewise a motion about it? Our Sun has Planets which it inlightens, why should not every fixed Star have the like? I have no Answer, said I, but that of Phedra to Enone, 'Tis you have said it.
explanations: The French "Ne me trompay-je point...?" is an interrogative phrase ("Am I not mistaken...?"), expressing the Marquise's dawning realization as she seeks confirmation. The English translation "I am not out of the way..." changes this into a declarative statement, making the Marquise sound more confident and assertive from the start, rather than tentatively arriving at an idea. This subtly alters the tone and her display of intellectual discovery.

The French "ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?" means "or [is it rather that] I see where you want to lead me?", indicating her perception of the philosopher's specific line of argument and her successful anticipation of it. The English "whether I go, or whether you lead me" replaces this with a new dichotomy concerning the agency behind her understanding (her own path vs. his guidance). This alters the original focus from her correctly anticipating his specific point to a broader statement about the origin of her insight, which is not present in the French text and subtly changes the dynamic of her learning process by emphasizing potential independence not highlighted in the original phrasing.

The French "M'allez-vous dire:" ("Are you going to tell me:") is a direct question, framing the Marquise's anticipation of the philosopher's words in an interrogative manner. The English translation "you are going to tell me," renders this as a declarative statement. This shift, while subtle, contributes to portraying the Marquise as more assertive in her prediction, rather than posing it as a question to the philosopher, thereby altering the tone of her interjection from inquiry to confident expectation.

chunks.sourceHtml: P088: Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, je ne suis plus rien. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes?. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte, en la partageant en mille & mille Tourbillons, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde..
chunks.manualHtml: P081: But, says she, why there's the Universe so big that I am lost in it, I know not where I am, I'm nothing. What, shall all be divided into Vortices confusedly thrown one among another? Shall evero Star be the Center of a Vortex as big perhaps as that wherein we are? Shall all the immense space that comprehends our Sun and our Planets be no more than a little Spot of the Universe? This confounds, perplexes and astonishes me. And, said I, for my share, I am wholly at ease. Were Heaven no more than that blue Vault where the Stars are nail'd, the Universe would seem small and narrow to me, and I should find my self straighten'd and oppress'd. But now that this Vault is of infinite more extent and profundity, in dividing it into a thousand thousand Vortices, methinks I breath with more liberty, and am in a more open Air; and most assuredly the Universe has wholly another Magnificence. Nature spar'd nothing in making it, but made a profusion of her Riches wholly worthy of her. Nothing can be represented so beautiful as that prodigious number of Vortices in the Center whereof is seated the Sun turning the Planets about him. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of those infinite Vortices, see on all sides the luminous centers of those Vortices which surround them, but they see not the Planets, which having but a feeble light borrowed from their Sun, do not propagate it beyond their World.

explanations: The Marquise's question "Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes?." (As many similar spaces as there are Fixed Stars?), which appears in the source text immediately before "Cela me confond...", is entirely omitted in the translation. The target text "This confounds..." thus directly follows her previous statement about the universe being a "little Spot." This omission removes a key element of her dawning comprehension of the universe's repetitive vastness, thereby manipulating the reader's perception by reducing the articulated scope of her intellectual and emotional overwhelm.

The translation significantly tones down the Marquise's emotional response. The French "me trouble" (troubles/disturbs me) is rendered as the more intellectual "perplexes me," and "m'épouvante" (frightens/terrifies me) becomes the much milder "astonishes me." This alteration changes the tone, presenting the Marquise as less viscerally affected and more cerebrally surprised, which can manipulate the reader's understanding of the profound, potentially unsettling impact of these new cosmological ideas.

The neutral French "est occupé par un Soleil" (is occupied by a Sun) is translated as "is seated the Sun." The verb "seated" personifies the Sun and imbues it with a sense of majesty or enthronement, a connotation absent in the original's more straightforward description. This subtle shift can manipulate the reader's perception by presenting the cosmos in a slightly more ordered or hierarchical manner than implied by Fontenelle's more naturalistic phrasing, potentially to align with traditional sensibilities.

The French idiom "n'avoir garde de faire quelque chose" (here, "ils n'ont garde d'en voir") conveys a strong sense of impossibility or that they are definitively unable to see them. The translation "but they see not the Planets" is a simple negation that loses this emphatic nuance. This alteration subtly weakens the certainty of the observational limitation being described, changing the tone from a strong assertion of impossibility to a more matter-of-fact statement.

chunks.sourceHtml: P089: Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons.. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.
chunks.manualHtml: P082: You offer me, said she, a kind of Perspective so long, that my eye cannot reach the end of it. I clearly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and afterward you shew me those of the Moon and the other Planets of our Vortex, truly clearly enough, but less than those of the Earth, and after them come the Inhabitants of the Planets of other Vortices. I protest to you they are wholly drown'd, and with all that I can do to see them, they are still almost wholly indiscernable. And in effect, are they not almost annihilated by the expression you are fain to make use of in speaking of them, you are fain to call them the Inhabitants of one of the Planets of one of those infinite Vortices. You must confess that you hardly know how to disingage us our selves, to whom the same expression agrees, from the midst of so many Worlds. For my share, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that from hence forward I shall have no value for any thing in it. Certainly men are so earnest in the pursuit of Greatness, form Design upon Design, and turmoile themselves so much, only because they are ignorant of these Vortices. These new Lights I intend shall apologize for me; and when any blame me for an unactive negligence, my Answer shall be, Ah! if you did but know what the fixed Stars are! Alexander, says, I, certainly knew nothing of them; for a certain Author, who holds that the Moon is inhabited, says seriously, that it was not possible that Aristotle should not be of an opinion so reasonable (for how could a Truth escape Aristotle?) but that he would say nothing of it for fear of displeasing Alexander, who would have fallen into despair to have seen a World that he could not conquer. The truth is, should any one have made a Mystery of the Vortices and fixed Stars, had they been known in those days, it had been an ill Complement to have told him of them. I my self, that know them, am not a little concern'd that I can make no profit by the Knowledge. They at best, in your opinion, cure only an unquiet and ambitious mind, which I am not troubl'd with; a little foolish inclination for the thing that's fair, is all my malady, and I doubt the Vortices can do me little kindness in that. The other Worlds, you say, make this seem little to you, but yet they obscure not the Lustre of your Eyes, nor spoil that pretty Mouth, those have still the same value in spight of all the Worlds.

They at best, in your opinion, cure only an unquiet and ambitious mind, which I am not troubl'd with; a little foolish inclination for the thing that's fair, is all my malady, and I doubt the Vortices can do me little kindness in that. The other Worlds, you say, make this seem little to you, but yet they obscure not the Lustre of your Eyes, nor spoil that pretty Mouth, those have still the same value in spight of all the Worlds.
explanations: The original 'Je vous avoüe' (I admit/confess to you) is translated as the stronger 'I protest to you,' which can imply objection or a more forceful declaration than a simple admission. Concurrently, 'tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement' (describing something as entirely in the deep background or very far off) is rendered as 'wholly drown'd.' This changes the imagery from optical distance and indistinctness to a more dramatic and potentially negative metaphor of being submerged or overwhelmed, thereby intensifying the Marquise's expression of difficulty or dismay beyond the likely original intent.

The original French, 'Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres' (I fully intend for my laziness to profit from my new insights), portrays the Marquise actively and wittily claiming her new knowledge as a justification for her laziness. The translation, 'These new Lights I intend shall apologize for me,' shifts the agency. Instead of her 'laziness profiting,' the 'new Lights' (knowledge) are posited as the agent that 'shall apologize.' This alters the Marquise's playful self-justification into a more passive construction where her knowledge makes excuses for her, subtly diminishing her active wit and changing the character of her reflection.

The phrase 'c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler' (literally, it would have been to pay one's court too badly to speak to him of it) refers to the act of currying favor with a superior and implies that speaking of such worlds to Alexander would have been a serious political miscalculation, potentially angering him. The translation 'it had been an ill Complement to have told him of them' significantly softens this meaning. An 'ill complement' suggests a social gaffe or an awkward remark, downplaying the original's implication of a politically imprudent and potentially perilous action when dealing with a powerful monarch. This alters the perceived astuteness regarding court politics.

The original French 'Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau' translates to 'A little weakness for what is beautiful,' where 'foiblesse' (weakness) can be a gentle or charming flaw. The translation 'a little foolish inclination for the thing that's fair' introduces the word 'foolish,' which is an addition not present in the source text. This interpolation adds a pejorative connotation, making the philosopher's self-described trait seem silly or irrational rather than a possibly refined sensibility. This subtly manipulates the reader's perception of the philosopher's character.

The French 'une belle bouche' (a beautiful mouth) is translated as 'that pretty Mouth.' In the context of compliments and aesthetics, 'belle' (beautiful) typically conveys a higher degree of admiration, depth, and aesthetic seriousness than the English 'pretty' (which aligns more closely with the French 'jolie'). This substitution subtly lessens the intensity and perceived value of the compliment paid by the philosopher, potentially diminishing the Marquise's praised attribute or the earnestness of the admiration expressed.

chunks.sourceHtml: P090: C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.
chunks.manualHtml:
P083: This Love, said the Marchioness, laughing, is a strange thing, it has a Salvo for all things and there's no System can do it harm. But tell me pray, and tell me freely, is your System true? Hide nothing from me, I promise you secrecy. To me it seems grounded only on a little Conveniency superficial enough. A Star fixed and luminous in it self like the Sun, ought consequently to be as the Sun is, the Center and Soul of a World, and to have Planets turning about him. Is not this of absolute necessity?

P084: Hark you, Madam, said I, since 'tis our humour to mix the Folly of Gallantry with our most serious Discourse, the Reasonings of Mathematicks are like those of Love; grant but a Lover the least thing, and you are presently ingag'd to make a farther Concession, and then another, and so to the Worlds end. In like manner grant a Mathematician the least Principle, he'l deduce a Consequence that you must likewise grant, and from that another, and whether you will or not he'l carry you so far as you hardly believe. These two sort of people take more than is given them. You allow, that when two things are alike in what appears to me, I may believe they are also alike in what appears not to me, if nothing otherways hinders me. From hence I concluded that the Moon is inhabited, because she resembles the Earth, and that the Planets are, because they resemble Moon. I find that the fixed Stars resemble our Sun, and I attribute to them all that is in him. You are now too far ingag'd to retire, you must e'en go on. But, says she, according to this Resemblance you make between the fixed Stars and our Sun, it must needs be that the people of another great Vortex do not see him but as a little fixed Star, which appears to them only in their night.

P084: Hark you, Madam, said I, since 'tis our humour to mix the Folly of Gallantry with our most serious Discourse, the Reasonings of Mathematicks are like those of Love; grant but a Lover the least thing, and you are presently ingag'd to make a farther Concession, and then another, and so to the Worlds end. You allow, that when two things are alike in what appears to me, I may believe they are also alike in what appears not to me, if nothing otherways hinders me. From hence I concluded that the Moon is inhabited, because she resembles the Earth, and that the Planets are, because they resemble Moon. I find that the fixed Stars resemble our Sun, and I attribute to them all that is in him. You are now too far ingag'd to retire, you must e'en go on. But, says she, according to this Resemblance you make between the fixed Stars and our Sun, it must needs be that the people of another great Vortex do not see him but as a little fixed Star, which appears to them only in their night.
explanations: The French pronoun "elle" (it/she) refers to "Une Etoile Fixe" (a fixed star), which is grammatically feminine. The English translation uses "him" to refer to the star. As "star" is a neuter noun in English (standard pronoun "it"), the choice of "him" introduces a masculine personification. This alters the original's gendering, which, even if primarily grammatical in French, becomes a specific personification choice in English, subtly shifting the perception of the celestial body.

The French original poses a direct question: "Is this of an absolute necessity?". The translation changes this to a negative question: "Is not this of absolute necessity?". This alteration shifts the tone of the Marquise's inquiry. A negative question often carries an underlying assumption or expectation (e.g., that it is *not* an absolute necessity, aligning with her expressed skepticism), making her challenge appear more pointed or her opinion more pre-formed, rather than a more neutral seeking of clarification.

The French phrase "à la fin cela va loin" translates to "in the end, that goes far" or "it leads to significant consequences." The English translation "and so to the Worlds end" dramatically amplifies this. "To the Worlds end" is a much stronger and more expansive expression, suggesting an almost boundless extent. This exaggeration intensifies the philosopher's analogy, altering the original's more measured tone.

The French "il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace" means "one must take the step / make the advance with good grace" or "willingly." The translation "you must e'en go on" (you must indeed/even go on) conveys the necessity of continuing but omits the crucial element of "de bonne grace" (with good grace, willingly). This omission changes the philosopher's counsel, making the progression of the argument seem more like an unavoidable, perhaps even reluctantly accepted, continuation for the Marquise, rather than a step she is encouraged to take willingly and gracefully. This subtly shifts the reader's perception of the persuasive dynamic.

chunks.sourceHtml: P091: Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, nostre Terre, par exemple, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?
chunks.manualHtml:
P085: No doubt on't, said I, our Sun is so near us, in comparison of the Suns of other Vortices, that his Light must have infinitely more of force upon our Eyes than theirs: so that we see him, and him only, when we see him; for he dazles all else. But in another great Vortex, another Sun prevails, and he takes his turn and dazles ours, which appears there only in the night with the other forreign Suns, that is, the fixed Stars, The people there seat him with them in the great Arch of Heaven, and there he makes a part perhaps of some Bull or Bear. As for the Planets that move about him, as our Earth, for example, they are not discerned so far off, and no body dreams of them. So all the Suns are Day Suns for the Vortices where they are placed, and Night Suns for all the other Vortices. In their World they are the only ones of their kind, every where else they serve only to make up the number of Stars.

P086: But yet, says she, notwithstanding this Equality, may not these Worlds differ in a thousand things? for a Resemblance in the main may admit of infinite varieties.

But in another great Vortex, another Sun prevails, and he takes his turn and dazles ours, which appears there only in the night with the other forreign Suns, that is, the fixed Stars, The people there seat him with them in the great Arch of Heaven, and there he makes a part perhaps of some Bull or Bear. As for the Planets that move about him, as our Earth, for example, they are not discerned so far off, and no body dreams of them. So all the Suns are Day Suns for the Vortices where they are placed, and Night Suns for all the other Vortices. In their World they are the only ones of their kind, every where else they serve only to make up the number of Stars.

P086: But yet, says she, notwithstanding this Equality, may not these Worlds differ in a thousand things? for a Resemblance in the main may admit of infinite varieties.
explanations: The French impersonal pronoun "On" (One/They/It is) in "On l'attache" (One attaches it / It is attached) describes a general act of classification or perception. The translation "The people there seat him" introduces specific, sentient agents ("The people there") and a more active, almost ceremonial verb ("seat him"). This shifts the meaning from a general astronomical perception or categorization to a deliberate action performed by imagined inhabitants of other worlds, subtly adding a layer of anthropomorphism and explicit agency not as foregrounded by the more abstract French.

The French "on n'y songe seulement pas" means "one doesn't even think/consider them," emphasizing a lack of basic cognitive awareness due to their invisibility. The translation "and no body dreams of them" alters the verb "songer" (which more commonly means to think/consider in this context) to the more poetic "dreams," and omits the crucial emphatic adverb "seulement" (even). This changes the tone from a factual observation about perception to a more whimsical or imaginative one, and loses the original's stress on how completely these planets are overlooked, thereby subtly shifting the reader's understanding of their insignificance.

The Marquise's question in French, "Ne faut-il pas ... que ... different" (Isn't it necessary that... / Don't... have to differ), conveys a strong sense of logical deduction and conviction. The English translation "may not these Worlds differ" significantly softens this assertion into a mere possibility. This lessens the perceived intellectual force and confidence of the Marquise's statement, potentially affecting the portrayal of a woman engaging in scientific reasoning, a key aspect of Fontenelle's work.

The French "car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?" (for a basis of resemblance nevertheless bears/produces infinite differences?) is phrased as a rhetorical question supporting the previous one, implying an affirmative answer. The translation "for a Resemblance in the main may admit of infinite varieties." changes this into a declarative statement and uses "may admit of," which suggests possibility rather than the more certain process implied by "ne laisse de porter" (does not fail to bear/produce). This dual shift (from question to statement, and from certainty to possibility) further weakens the logical force and assertive tone of the Marquise's argument as presented in the original.

chunks.sourceHtml: P092: Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.
chunks.manualHtml: P087: Most certain, said I, but the difficulty is to guess what or how. What know I? one Vortex has more Planets that turn about his Sun, another has fewer. In the one there are subordinate Planets, which move about others that are bigger, in another ther's no such thing. Here they all crowd together about their Sun, and make, as it were, a little Ball, beyond which a great void space extends as far as the neighbouring Vortices. In another place they take their course toward the extremities of the Vortex, and leave the middle void. I doubt not likewise but there may be some Vortices desert, and without Planets; and others, whose Sun not being exactly in the Center, has a true motion, and carrys his Planets with him. Others that rise or fall in respect of their Sun, according to the change of the poise that sustains them. In fine, what more would you have? There's e'en enough for a man that was never out of his own Vortex.
